thread.title: Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party - USA TODAY
thread.title_full: Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party - USA TODAY

title: Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party - USA TODAY
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party The Chicago Cubs, those loveable losers of the past, are now the powerful winners of the present, knocking off their rival St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, and moving onto the National League Championship Series. Post to Facebook Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party The Chicago Cubs, those loveable losers of the past, are now the powerful winners of the present, knocking off their rival St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, and moving onto the National League Championship Series. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1Lt8d8D Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party Bob Nightengale , USA TODAY Sports 7:55 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Kyle Schwarber rounds the bases after a solo home run in the seventh inning. (Photo: Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CHICAGO - They danced in the aisles Tuesday at Wrigley Field, screamed until their lungs ached, clapped until their hands were raw, and shook the joint with unadulterated joy. 
The Chicago Cubs, those loveable losers of the past, are now the powerful winners of the present, knocking off their rival St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, and moving onto the National League Championship Series. 
It was the first time in the 139-year history of the franchise that the Cubs clinched a playoff series at home, turning Wrigleyville into the world’s biggest outdoor party. 
The Cubs, who will play the winner of the New York Mets-Los Angeles Dodgers NL Division Series, now are four victories away from winning their first pennant in 70 years, keeping the dream alive of winning their first World Series since 1918. 
“It's incredible," said Cubs first baseman Anthony Rizzo, who hit the go-ahead home run in the sixth inning, breaking a 4-4 tie. “It's one of those moments, one of those magical moments at Wrigley that hopefully people are talking about for generations and generations.’’ 
They anticipated that magic moment all afternoon long, with the crowd standing on its feet for most of the game, before taking the party to the streets. 
The Cardinals managed to silence the crowd just twice, when Stephen Piscotty hit a two-run homer two minutes into the game, and Brandon Moss tied the game with a run-scoring double in the sixth. 
Yet, these are the new Cubs, not the ones your grandfather grew up watching. 
Just when it appeared that the Cardinals were about to spoil the party, it was Rizzo who came the rescue. Rizzo launched his second home run in as many nights off Cardinals lefty reliever Kevin Siegrist, deep into the right-field bleachers. Your browser does not support iframes. 
One inning later, rookie Kyle Schwarber launched a home run that may be talked about forever in this city. 
Schwarber hit the ball so hard that it carried the bleachers and landed atop the right-field scoreboard, sending the party into full force. He is the first Cubs player to reach the scoreboard, which was installed this summer. The Cubs' Kyle Schwarber just hit a baseball to the moon 
Yet, it was Rizzo who was perhaps was most responsible for the Cubs’ offensive show. He started the second-inning attack simply by using his head. Rizzo, seeing third base vacated while the Cardinals moved into a shift to the right side, beat it by merely pounding the ball into the ground on the left side. A routine chopper turned into a critical leadoff single. 
Starlin Castro grounded out, but Schwarber followed with a single, brining Miguel Montero to the plate, and sending Cubs manager Joe Maddon’s mind spinning. 
It was the moment Maddon let everyone know that he was treating this game like a do-or-die, wanting no part of trying to beat the Cardinals in Game 5 at Busch Stadium. He called the bullpen, and ordered Justin Grimm to warm up, knowing he might need a pinch-hitter for Hammel, who stood in the on-deck circle. 
Montero struck out, Grimm sat down, and it looked like Maddon’s decision to bat Hammel eighth and not ninth was about to blow up in his face. 
Only, these are the new Cubs, with a manager that has had the golden touch all season. 
So, of course, Hammel singles up the middle, scoring Castro, and cutting the Cardinals’ lead to 2-1. 
Shortstop Javier Baez, in the starting lineup only because Addison Russell strained his hamstring Monday night, swung mightily on the first pitch he saw. 
And drove John Lackey’s hanging breaking ball into the right-field bleachers. 
Three-run homer. 
Wrigley Field absolutely erupted. 
The Cubs had a 4-2 lead, and Maddon made sure it was going to stick, yanking Hammel out of the game after just three innings, and turning the final 18 outs to his bullpen. 
The Cardinals, after winning 100 games, are now done for the season, their earliest departure since 2010. 
The Cardinals had been in the National League Championship Series the last four years, winning two pennants and a World Series, but it was the Cubs who finally ended the Cardinals’ reign. 
This is a franchise that has won 11 World Series titles, and hosted 140 postseason games, but no more games will be played this year at Busch Stadium. 
Now, it’s the Cubs who have visions of the World Series dancing in their sleep, with tickets going for an average of $6,750, $6,754 and $8,443 for their three potential games, according to Bloomberg. 
So imagine just how high they might go if the Cubs actually get there, and win the NLCS. 
Yes, it’s crazy in Chicago, with the city falling back in love with a team that won 24 more games than a year ago, playing with four rookies in the starting lineup. 
And a manager who had them believing anything was possible. 
“He creates the perfect environment for players to be themselves and perform at the highest level,’’ Cubs president Theo Epstein said, “while having fun. 
“We would not be here without Joe at this moment in time.’’ 
This is what the Cubs’ management envisioned all along, only, not this year. 
This was supposed to happen next year. 
These Cubs refused to wait. 
“I think,’’ Maddon said, “the whole city is ready for this.’’ 
You think? 
It started back in spring training when Rizzo reminded everyone of his prediction they would win the division, Maddon predicted 90 victories and a postseason berth, and catcher Miguel Montero had T-shirts made that read: #Wearegood.’’ 
“I just want to send a message to our team, pretty much,’’ Montero said. “I want to let them know what I feel about our team, and what I believe about every single guy in our clubhouse. Then, if we don’t believe that we are good or not, we’re going to have a chance. 
“So we have to believe it to actually accomplish the goal.’’ 
Well, the Cubs have got the whole city believing that nothing can stop them now. 
“We feel great about our chances," Castro said. "I've been through lot of bad moments here, but now we have found a way to be a winning team."
